item.content:encoded:
info

This review was written as part of the Hanbit Media I am a Reviewer activity, where the book was provided for review.

Book Info​

tip

Click the book image to visit the Kyobobook store!

image.png

  • Title: Developer Technical Interview Notes
  • Authors: Jay Alammar, Marten Hulingdorst
  • Translator: Park Haesun
  • Publisher: Hanbit Media
  • Release Date: June 10, 2025

Intro​

Large Language Models (LLMs) are now essential knowledge not just for developers, but also for researchers, students, planners, and many other fields. While I’ve studied LLM principles and applications over time, I’ve struggled to solidify my fundamentals amid the flood of new tools and techniques. Hands-On LLM gave me the chance to systematically review core concepts and practice hands-on exercises—all in one place.

I picked up this book wanting to revisit LLMs in a structured way, and I’m genuinely satisfied with the result. Studying LLMs feels like an endless journey—new models, tools, and approaches keep emerging. That’s why this book’s emphasis on fundamentals resonated deeply with me.

Book Review​

The Best Choice for “Relearning” LLMs​

This isn’t just an introductory guide for LLM beginners. Even if you already know concepts like Transformers, Fine-Tuning, or Embeddings, this book excels as a guide to connect those dots cohesively.

Previously scattered ideas from blogs and papers finally clicked when I read Chapter 3 (on Transformer architecture). The intuitive visuals and seamless integration of hands-on exercises made me repeatedly think, “Oh, that’s how it works!”

Visual Explanations + Hands-On Practice​

The book’s strongest points are its visualizations and practical exercises.

Each chapter includes dozens of color diagrams, example illustrations, and code output images, making even complex concepts easy to grasp.

With setups for Hugging Face, Colab, and other tools, you can jump straight into practice without extra environment setup. Real-world examples like prompt engineering, clustering, and RAG pipeline construction helped me build practical skills.

Personally, Chapter 5 (BERTopic), Chapter 7 (LangChain’s ReAct), and Chapter 12 (Fine-Tuning Generative Models) stood out as especially insightful.

Not a Shortcoming, but a Clear Audience Prerequisite​

This book isn’t for complete beginners. As the authors note in the preface, some Python and machine learning background is necessary for smooth reading.

Additionally, it doesn’t cover infrastructure, cost optimization, or deployment for production—so readers seeking real-world application details may need supplementary resources.

However, the book’s focus is clear: “Understand LLMs deeply and learn to work with them hands-on.” And it delivers on that promise admirably.

Target Audience​

  • Anyone who wants to revisit LLM principles and key concepts through visual explanations and practical exercises
  • Readers who’ve pieced together knowledge from blogs or papers and want a structured, comprehensive review
  • Those looking to systematically learn LLM applications like chatbots, embedding-based search, and prompt optimization
  • Learners who want to follow recent LLM trends (LangChain, RAG, LoRA) through hands-on practice

item.title: 📖Developer Technical Interview Notes
item.description: A 20-Year Kakao Interviewer's Guide to Landing a Job/Transitioning at Big Tech Companies
item.content:encoded:
info

This post is part of the Hanbit Media I am a Reviewer activity, written after receiving the book.

Book Info​

tip

Click the book cover to visit the Kyobobook store!

  • Title: Technical Interview Notes for Developers
  • Author: Namhee Lee
  • Publisher: Hanbit Media
  • Release Date: April 7, 2025

Intro​

It’s been a while since I last applied for a book review. My internship is almost over, and I’ve been thinking about my next steps—when I saw this book on technical interviews, I knew I had to apply. Written by a 20-year veteran interviewer from Kakao, it’s essentially a guide for landing or switching jobs at big tech companies. Reading it gave me a clear picture of what technical interviews entail and how to prepare.

Book Review​

A Technical Interview Guide from an Intern’s Perspective​

Lately, I’ve heard a lot about how tough the developer job market is. Even as an intern, I know that whether I aim for full-time conversion or apply elsewhere, coding tests and technical interviews are unavoidable.

While I’m slowly getting the hang of real-world work, I still felt lost about how to write a resume or what to study for technical interviews. Then I found this book—and it turned out to be a surprisingly practical guide.

Gaining Direction in an Overwhelming Job Search​

The book smoothly outlines the entire hiring process: resume preparation → coding tests/technical interviews → post-interview steps. It’s not just another algorithm problem book; it also covers how to analyze job postings, resume-writing tips, and frequently asked interview questions.

My favorite parts were:

  • Job posting analysis: I learned how to identify skills I need to improve, beyond just skimming the listing.
  • Resume pitfalls: Seeing examples of rejected resumes helped me avoid common mistakes.
  • Technical interview prep: The book clarified what to study for topics like databases, OS, networks, and architecture.
  • Study habits & growth mindset: It reinforced how to approach career growth, which was invaluable for my long-term planning.

Why Interns Should Start Preparing Early​

As an intern, keeping up with real work is already hectic, and preparing for full-time conversion feels rushed. But this book made me realize that starting now—even gradually—will make the process much less daunting later.

Technical interviews require a surprisingly broad and deep knowledge base. Balancing prep with work isn’t easy, but at least having a roadmap gives me peace of mind.

What I loved most is that the book goes beyond technical skills—it also discusses the mindset needed for growth and work. It’s packed with insights for building a sustainable career.

Recommended Audience​

I’d recommend this to any junior developer. In fact, anyone below senior level would benefit—it covers everything from resumes and portfolios to technical and behavioral interviews, offering practical tips for the entire hiring process.

item.title: 🎬The first and final post. The end.
item.description: A truly wonderful and warm community
item.content:encoded:
Geulddo Season 10​

Wrap-Up​

It’s hard to believe that Geulddo Season 10 is already over. Time really flies—it’s been six months since I started Geulddo. Before writing this post, I revisited my first and last Geulddo start post after a long time. It was a glimpse into my past self, filled with unreasonable goals and grand resolutions. I wonder how I ever thought I could tackle all of that. I guess I just set big goals, even if I knew I’d fail some.

While drafting this, I briefly considered using headings like "What I Did in Geulddo, What I Gained from Geulddo," but I didn’t want to make it too formal. Looking back, I didn’t participate as actively as I’d hoped. I failed to meet my goal of writing without skipping days, and my aim to have coffee chats with diverse people also fell short by my own standards. The small group activities didn’t involve skiing or sledding—just casual hangouts. I wanted to explore more through Geulddo, and it’s a bit regrettable that I couldn’t.

However, Geulddo gave me a sense of relief. During October and November, while I was juggling job preparation, the small groups provided a much-needed breather. Reflecting on October, I have no idea how I managed graduation project prep, job hunting, small group activities (gaming), schoolwork, and study sessions all at once. Despite the stress of that hectic life, being part of a group left no room for loneliness. That’s definitely something I’m grateful for.

Geulddo also helped me understand myself better. I never deeply considered what I truly wanted to do before. If I felt like studying tech, I’d just do it. I lived practically: university studies, then job hunting post-graduation. But during a coffee chat, someone casually asked, "What do you want to do?" I’d never thought about that, so I couldn’t answer immediately. Since then, I’ve made a habit of regularly asking myself what I truly desire, checking if my actions align with my genuine aspirations.

Lastly, Geulddo became a medium that made me ponder how to write better. Before, my mindset was, "This is my blog, so I’ll write whatever I want." Now, I think about what readers might find interesting. That’s a huge step for me—it’s shifted my perspective to a more audience-centric approach.

What’s Next?​

My short-term goal is to wrap up my current internship well. With about three months left (roughly two and a half if you exclude the evaluation period), I want to live a slightly more intentional life than I have been. I’ll try to plan systematically.

Long-term, I aim to clarify what I truly want and continue self-discovery. I plan to read more books, study deeper, and dedicate more time to both than I do now.

While this is abstract, I’ll keep detailed plans to myself—they’re TMI.

Geulddo, thank you for everything! 🙏

item.title: 📖Deep Learning from Scratch 1 (Remastered Edition)
item.description: Deep Learning Theory and Implementation with Python
item.content:encoded:
info

This post is a book review written as part of the Hanbit Media "I am a Reviewer" activity, for which the book was provided.

Book Info​

tip

Click the book image to visit the Kyobobook store!

  • Title: Deep Learning from Scratch 1 (Remastered Edition)
  • Author: Saito Goki
  • Translator: Gaepyeon Lee (개앞맵시)
  • Publisher: Hanbit Media
  • Release Date: January 24, 2025

Intro​

Once again, I’m grateful to participate in Hanbit Media’s "I am a Reviewer" program in 2025. It’s truly a privilege to read books, write reviews, and access Hanbit Media’s publications more easily than others. This time, I read Deep Learning from Scratch 1 (Remastered Edition). Originally published in January 2017, this book has played a significant role in deep learning education in Korea. It’s a book that has genuinely helped many people take their first steps into deep learning. The remastered edition makes it even more reader-friendly.

Book Review​

For my previous review of the original edition, you can visit this link. In this review, I’ll focus on the changes and improvements in the remastered version rather than summarizing the content. If you’re curious about other updates, I recommend reading [Rebirth Story] Deep Learning from Scratch 1 (Remastered Edition).

Full-Color Design​

The most noticeable change is the switch from black-and-white to full-color pages. While the original’s monochrome aesthetic had its charm—evoking the feel of classic papers—the new color scheme makes the content more engaging and visually accessible. It’s refreshing to see publishers prioritizing reader experience, even if production costs rise.

Code Improvements​

In the first edition, managing working directories was crucial, but the remastered version simplifies this process.

Previously, code was only available as Python files, but now it’s also provided in Jupyter Notebook format for Google Colab. This is a fantastic improvement—readers can experiment with code directly in the browser without setting up a local environment.

Additionally, the code has been updated to address warnings from libraries like matplotlib and numpy, ensuring compatibility with modern setups.

Expanded Series Overview​

The book now includes an introduction to other titles in the series. If you’re hooked after reading this one, the subsequent books offer deeper dives. I’m particularly excited about the upcoming Deep Learning from Scratch 6, which will focus on LLMs.

Chapter 8, the final chapter, includes more detailed "NOTE" sections compared to the original. These notes guide readers to other books in the series for advanced topics—a feature I appreciate. A good book should always point you toward the next step, and this one does that well.

Recommended Audience​

This book is ideal for anyone looking to start their deep learning journey. After reading it, you’ll have a solid foundation in the fundamentals. I also recommend exploring the other books in the series afterward. Whenever friends, colleagues, or peers ask me how to begin with deep learning, I always point them to this book first. It’s an excellent starting point and truly worth the read.

item.title: Hands-on Generative AI Development with Amazon Bedrock
item.description: Now AI Becomes Your Development Tool - The Complete AWS Gen AI Guide for Practitioners
item.content:encoded:
Book Info​

tip

Click the book image to go to the Kyobobook site!

​

  • Title: Hands-on Generative AI Development with Amazon Bedrock
  • Authors: Lim Ji-hoon, Choi Sung-woo
  • Publisher: Digital Books
  • Release Date: 2025-01-10

Intro​

Recently, I had to use AWS Bedrock at work, so I was studying the official documentation. While browsing LinkedIn, I found out this book was published and decided to buy and read it. Microsoft and Google are dominating the generative AI space, but Amazon recently unveiled the Nova model and seems to be pushing harder with Bedrock. Though a bit late, I think it’s a positive move. AWS Bedrock is a platform for using generative AI models, and I wanted to learn how to apply it in real-world scenarios through this book.

## Book Review​

Bedrock​

Bedrock is a fully managed generative AI platform provided by AWS. It collaborates with partners like AI21 Labs, Anthropic, Cohere, Meta, Mistral AI, and Stability AI to offer various models. Unfortunately, OpenAI is not included. The book covers how to use Bedrock via the website, how to apply generative AI models through code, and the features Bedrock provides.

Overall Book Review​

The book is organized into 9 chapters. Uniquely, it starts with Chapter 0—a rare sight outside appendices, which I found amusing and very "developer-like." Chapter 0 kindly guides readers through AWS sign-up, IAM (which can be daunting for beginners), and setting up the AWS CLI for coding. Even those new to AWS should find this book accessible.

Chapter 1 briefly explains what generative AI is and how Bedrock differs from SageMaker. Chapter 2 introduces the Bedrock website’s playground for testing models, model overviews, and simple coding exercises. Chapter 3 covers prompt engineering, while Chapter 4 explains how to implement RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) with Bedrock, including its Knowledge Bases feature. This section also integrates additional AWS services.

Chapter 5 discusses building Agents with Bedrock, and Chapter 6 explores model training—impressively, Bedrock supports Fine-Tuning and Continued Pre-Training. I recall doing this with SageMaker before, but now it’s unnecessary. The book also explains importing external models for training.

Chapter 7 covers operational features, including Guardrails for detecting hallucinations—a surprising and useful tool. Model evaluation features are also highlighted, showing Bedrock’s robustness. Finally, Chapter 8 briefly introduces the latest Bedrock updates.

Target Audience​

If you’re interested in generative AI—especially RAG, Agents, or practical applications—this book is a great read. Even without AWS experience, you’ll find it approachable. Generative AI costs scale with usage, so experimenting with models isn’t prohibitively expensive. Dive into this book to explore various models hands-on!

item.title: ✨2024 Reflection
item.description:
Looking back on 2024 (Note: The original text is incomplete, as it only says "Looking back on 2024" without further content. If you'd like to expand this into a reflective essay or add specific content about 2024, I'd be happy to help!)
Since you requested only the translation, here is the direct rendering: **"Looking back on 2024"**
Let me know if you'd like to develop this further!
item.content:encoded:
It's hard to believe how quickly time has passed. The year has flown by so fast. This year was filled with significant changes and growth for me. In this post, I want to reflect on the transformations and progress I’ve experienced in 2024.

Graduation Project​

I’ve been gradually training myself to read papers while studying ML, and now I realize it was all preparation for this graduation project. I don’t think I’ve ever read as many papers as I did this year. Although I didn’t follow the latest papers, I’ve read most of the seminal works in Computer Vision, such as GANs and NeRF.

Still, I chose not to pursue a research career. While learning new technologies was fun, I doubted my ability to write groundbreaking papers that would impact the world. If I ever wanted to go to grad school, I thought working first and then attending a part-time or overseas program could be a good option. So, I decided to become an engineer—studying, implementing, and creating value through technology.

Although it wasn’t an official research internship, I’m grateful to BCML for giving me an indirect experience of lab life through my graduation project. I truly felt the professor’s dedication. Every meeting was conducted in English, which was a unique experience. Except for special occasions like holidays or exams, we had weekly meetings. Honestly, I didn’t expect such guidance since we weren’t official lab interns. Of course, our project’s success would benefit the lab, but I’m still thankful for the time and direction they provided. I’d also like to thank the TAs who helped us every week, guiding us on how to implement and proceed with the project. Their support in setting up experiments, tools, and environments was invaluable.

In return, our team worked hard every week to produce meaningful results. I want to express my gratitude to my team through this post. They took responsibility and saw the project through for almost a year. It was the best team and project I’ve had in college. This effort eventually led us to win an award at the graduation project exhibition.

GDSC​

This community leaves me with a lot of regrets. The first cohort ended without continuing to a second one. I was an ML member and participated in the Solution Challenge, where I worked on a chatbot project using LangChain and some GCP services.

I was also disappointed that the ML paper study group, where we read and presented papers, was discontinued. It would have greatly improved my presentation skills. Still, the monthly seminars gave me a chance to present in front of others for the first time, helping me grow.

GeulTto (글또)​

Thanks to GeulTto, I wrote more blog posts this year than last. I’ve always had the habit of writing while studying, but I didn’t post them online. The first reason was that I didn’t want to write the same content as others. I wanted my posts to reflect my unique experiences. Otherwise, I felt they’d be no different from wikis or other blogs. This challenge still isn’t easy, but I keep trying to write differently.

Second, writing for myself is simple and straightforward, but blogging requires considering the reader. For example, when writing technical posts, I want them to be easy to understand. This makes the writing process longer. I’ve learned not to stress too much about pleasing everyone.

On a side note, I spent a lot of time in the GeulTto gaming channel, "GameTto." With stress from job prep and the graduation project, playing League of Legends with GeulTto members once a week was a great relief. I also had fun meeting offline at T1 Base Camp. Additionally, attending the backend-infra meetup unexpectedly helped me. Although I’d already secured an internship, I felt unprepared. At the meetup, someone offered to introduce me to employees at the company I’d joined, which led to valuable connections. I’m truly grateful for that opportunity and to GeulTto for fostering such relationships.

NIPA-Google ML Bootcamp Collaborative Project​

During the break, I spent 3 hours daily commuting to participate in a practical project run by NIPA and Google’s ML Bootcamp. I considered quitting multiple times but persisted, believing I’d gain something. In the end, I completed a chatbot project for my resume and gained experience collaborating with five people. Mid-project, I visited Google Korea and had the chance to talk to Googlers. I remember asking a lot of questions—probably more than anyone else.

Job Preparation​

I started job hunting in September. First, I organized my projects and tailored my resume to the job descriptions (JDs) of the companies and roles I was applying for. While my projects weren’t perfect, I highlighted the technologies I used to match the JDs. I invested everything into one company. It took a month just to finalize my resume, constantly asking, "How can I stand out?"

During this process, I want to thank someone who helped me. In May, our school hosted alumni from various companies. One speaker was a senior from my university and a current employee at the company I now work for. I attended the talk and got their business card. Later, in October, after drafting my resume, I cold-mailed them for feedback. Thankfully, they gladly helped, and with their input, I passed the document screening.

As a foreign company, I expected a slow process, but it was surprisingly fast. Previously, Google’s intern process felt sluggish, so this one seemed quicker. Each stage’s result came out the next day or within two days.

After passing the document screening, things got tough. Preparing for the graduation exhibition, tech interviews, and loop interviews all at once was overwhelming. For tech interviews, I reviewed and memorized all my CS knowledge. For loop interviews, I organized my experiences using the STAR format and practiced speaking. Eventually, after the exhibition and loop interviews, I was accepted as a cloud intern. I feel incredibly lucky.

Reading​

  • Deep Learning Fundamentals
  • Becoming a Better Programmer
  • Developing LLM-Based AI Services with LangChain
  • AI Truth
  • Flow: The Psychology of Optimal Experience
  • The One Thing
  • Open
  • Software Engineer Guidebook
  • What Makes a Winning Team

I read 9 books this year. One was for self-study, two were self-help books I chose, and the rest were provided by Hanbit Media. Since 2021, they’ve greatly contributed to my growth. I want to express my gratitude through this reflection. I hope to continue participating in their "I’m a Reviewer" program next year.

Even though I’ll be busy as an intern next year, I plan to read more, including novels.

item.title: ✨November Reflection
item.description: Reflecting on a busy November filled with graduation projects and job preparation.
item.content:encoded:
The reason retrospectives are always scary might be because they force me to face my past self from the previous month. Just like October, I didn’t live up to my own expectations in November, and I’m afraid to write this reflection—but I’m trying anyway.

Reading​

  • Software Engineer Guidebook

As mentioned in my book review, this is a must-read for any software engineer. As we gain experience, our roles expand or change. This book helped me understand the roles and skills required as I grow from a junior to a staff engineer. It also includes some soft skills, making it very helpful. I plan to read it again before work.

Personal Study​

In my university’s liberal arts math course, I revisited computer-related topics like Huffman coding and the JPEG compression process. I also got a condensed introduction to challenging fields such as information theory, cryptography, data mining, artificial intelligence, and fractal theory.

Graduation Project​

I prepared for the graduation project exhibition by reviewing the papers we applied, the progress meeting slides, and more. The exhibition concluded successfully, though I was too nervous to explain well when three professors evaluated our work. We received a Consolation Prize, which felt rewarding after all our efforts. While I aimed for the highest Grand Prize, I was grateful just to be recognized, as there were many outstanding projects.

I had planned to write a separate retrospective on the graduation project but will likely skip it—maybe just mention it briefly in my 2024 reflection.

Job Preparation​

Resume Writing​

I’ve finalized my English resume and applied to my top-choice company. I passed the document screening and completed the OA (Online Assessment), and now I’m preparing for interviews. After this process, I’ll draft a Korean resume as well.

Organizing Past Projects​

I’m still organizing projects from school, some with over 2,000 lines of code. It’s been challenging to document everything, especially since I’m rewriting comments in English and studying the overall structure. I’m focusing on the projects listed in my resume.

Algorithms​

My original goal was to solve three problems daily, but I’ve scaled it back to one due to time constraints. I solve problems on LeetCode (Easy/Medium) within a set morning timeframe, compare my solutions with official ones, and reflect on approaches. This process consumes more time than expected.

Networking​

Gangbuk Eodosaram Itto (There Are People in Gangbuk Too)​

I attended a Gangbuk Eodosaram Itto meetup through GeulTto. Contrary to expectations, it was held in Chungmuro, not Nowon, and it was fun to travel far for a change. We discussed development, grad school, and various topics, which helped me clarify some concerns. My biggest worry—“I don’t know which field to pursue”—was addressed with advice to either focus on versatility or specialize deeply. Both awkward and enjoyable, the meetup was a great chance to share and hear others’ struggles and experiences. Community support is powerful.

Carrot Tech Meetup​

I attended the Carrot Tech Meetup and listened to Data/ML talks, plus networked with Carrot teams (though recruitment networking slots filled too fast). My takeaway: I’ll no longer consider MLOps or Data Engineering roles. These paths usually require prior experience or internal transitions, and even though I wondered if new grads could break in, I’ve decided to let it go—especially after a related study group.

If aiming for MLE (Machine Learning Engineer), strong ML fundamentals and coding test prep are key. User service experience is a plus but not expected for new grads. Kaggle projects were also recommended.

English Study​

I tried using ChatGPT’s Advanced Voice Mode for speaking practice, but it was surprisingly difficult. Speaking from scratch was a new challenge, and I couldn’t stick with it as a habit.

November Goals​

  • Balance reading/networking without hindering job prep
  • Solve 1 LeetCode problem daily
  • Interview preparation
  • Finalize graduation project exhibition
  • No new study groups

Compared to October, my goals are simpler—interviews take priority, leaving little room for else.

I’ve been detailed, but I’m still afraid of failing my own promises. Since I’ve pinned this on my blog, I’ll try not to be ashamed of myself. Regardless of the outcome, I’ll give it my best.

item.title: 📖Software Engineer Guidebook
item.description: Essential Career Management Secrets Every Software Engineer Should Know, from Junior to Leader
item.content:encoded:
info

This review was written as part of the Hanbit Media "I am a Reviewer" activity, where I was provided with the book.

Book Info​

tip

Click the book image to go to the Kyobook store!

  • Title: The Software Engineer Guidebook
  • Author: Gergely Orosz
  • Translator: Minseok Lee
  • Publisher: Hanbit Media
  • Release Date: October 30, 2024

Intro​

I’ve been swamped with job preparation lately. Still, I want to give myself credit for squeezing in time to read this book little by little. I almost didn’t get to finish the parts I needed, but after securing an internship, I finally had time to sit down with it at home. The phrase “From Junior to Leader” made me wonder, “Is this even a book for someone like me who hasn’t landed a job yet?” But curiosity got the better of me, and I dove in.

Book Review​

Overall Review​

Part 1 covers how to design and manage your career—touching on performance reviews, promotions, job changes, and how to prepare for them. It’s packed with topics juniors would eventually grapple with. I was especially struck by the advice on keeping a work journal to document your contributions.

Part 2 dives into how to work well as a developer. While some points might seem obvious to seasoned engineers, the granular tips are refreshing, especially for newcomers. Part 3, labeled for senior engineers, isn’t exclusive to them. It discusses time management, team collaboration, testing, and architecture—all valuable for juniors who’ll eventually need these skills. It’s like a sneak peek into senior life, and that’s a plus.

Part 4 focuses on leadership—project management, decision-making, launches, and stakeholders. The stakeholder section stood out; it’s not just for tech leads but anyone dealing with non-technical collaborators. Part 5 tackles staff and principal engineer roles, emphasizing business acumen and customer-centric thinking—skills even juniors should start cultivating.

Finally, Part 6 wraps up with the timeless advice, “Never Stop Learning,” and an appendix featuring insights from Korean senior engineers on growth, AI’s impact, and more. These real-world perspectives were a highlight—I don’t often get to hear from such experienced professionals.

Recommended Audience​

This book is for every engineer, regardless of level. I’d especially recommend it to those before their first job. While most learn processes on the job, starting with this mindset could make the transition smoother. Plus, revisiting it later might reveal new insights. I’m grateful I found this before stepping into the workplace.

item.title: Why Alpine Linux Should Be Avoided When Choosing a Docker Base Image for Python Projects
item.description:
Troubleshooting Issues When Deploying a Python Backend with Docker (Note: The original Korean text was a title/heading, so the translation reflects that structure. If you need elaboration on specific problems/solutions, additional context would be required.)
**Alternative (if intended as a sentence):** "I encountered and resolved issues while attempting to deploy a Python backend using Docker."
Let me know if you'd like a detailed troubleshooting guide or specific problem-solution pairs!
item.content:encoded:
Introduction​

I encountered several errors while moving a Django blog project to Docker. This post shares the knowledge I gained while resolving these issues.

First Problem​

Compatibility Issue Between Alpine Linux and cryptography​

While building after creating the Dockerfile and docker-compose.yml, I encountered the following error:

ERROR: No matching distribution found for cryptography==3.4.7

The Docker image version and cryptography version in requirements.txt were as follows:

FROM python:3.8-alpine
cryptography==3.4.7

Solution​

I realized this was a compatibility issue between Alpine Linux and the cryptography package, which implements cryptographic algorithms in Python. After consulting the official cryptography documentation, I found a solution.

In summary, cryptography uses Rust for building. This means cargo, Rust's package manager and build tool, must also be installed. I added the following to the Dockerfile:

$ sudo apk add gcc musl-dev python3-dev libffi-dev openssl-dev cargo

This resolved the first issue.

Second Problem​

Build Process Took Too Long and Failed​

After adding the above commands to the Dockerfile and rebuilding, another error occurred. The build process kept running indefinitely (showing "still running") for about 10 minutes before eventually stopping.

Solution​

After extensive research, I revisited the cryptography documentation and GitHub issues to find a similar case.

The key points from the issue were:

  1. Building Python packages on Alpine Linux is slow, especially in CI/CD environments where rebuilding is frequent.
  2. Uploading Alpine-compatible wheels requires changes to pip/wheel/packaging, which involves ongoing PEP discussions.
  3. Installing Python packages properly on newer Alpine versions requires the latest Rust compiler.
  4. These issues are documented, and no improvements are currently planned. If further issues arise, new issues or PRs should be submitted.

The core takeaway was that Alpine Linux itself was the problem. Switching the base image resolved the issue:

FROM python:3.8-slim-buster

But why did this happen? Let's explore the reasons.

Why Alpine Linux Is Not Ideal for Python Environments​

I initially chose Alpine Linux because it’s smaller and faster to build compared to Ubuntu. However, it’s not well-suited for Python environments.

The key difference lies in the C standard libraries used. Most Linux distributions use GNU C Library (glibc) for C programs, including Python. However, Alpine Linux uses musl libc for lightweight optimization. Since musl doesn’t support Wheel binaries compiled with glibc, it downloads .tar.gz files instead of .whl files. This means all Python packages with C extensions must be compiled from source, leading to longer build times and larger image sizes.

Most modern Python packages include precompiled Wheel binaries on PyPI, which are essentially ZIP archives with a .whl extension. These speed up installations significantly. However, Alpine Linux bypasses this optimization.

Drawbacks of Using Alpine Linux for Python:​

  1. Slow builds due to source compilation.
  2. Larger image sizes from compiled dependencies.
  3. Wasted time waiting for builds.
  4. Potential runtime bugs from compatibility issues.

For Python projects, Debian-based slim images or Ubuntu-based images are more suitable than Alpine Linux.

🌐 References​

  • Cryptography installation
  • Dependencies to build on Alpine Linux?
  • How to Build Docker Images Efficiently
  • Using Alpine Can Make Python Docker Builds 50x Slower
  • The Best Docker Base Image for Python Applications

item.title: ✨October Reflection
item.description: Looking back on a busy October filled with graduation projects and job preparation.
item.content:encoded:
In my previous post, I wrote about my October Goals. I’m writing this to check if I achieved them. I’m a bit scared to write this because I didn’t live up to October, but I’ll try anyway.

Reading​

  • Flow: The Psychology of Optimal Experience (몰입의 즐거움)
  • The One Thing (원씽)
  • Open (오픈)

I read these three books. While reading, I reflected a lot and questioned whether I’m trying to do too much. I’ve been eliminating things that I think aren’t immediately necessary for me right now.

My goal was to read an hour before bed, and I did well for the first week. But I got too sleepy and found it annoying to keep proving I was reading, so I stopped. Now, I read when I feel like it or on weekend mornings when I have time.

I’m currently reading Software Engineer Guidebook (소프트웨어 엔지니어 가이드북). If I finish this and have time, I’d like to read Not Going My Way (작별하지 않는다) by Han Kang.

Study Groups​

  • ETL Study (Learning Spark): This was a study group with data engineers and software engineers. I learned a lot from their real-world experiences. My only regret is that I couldn’t complete the project after finishing the book because my graduation project became too time-consuming.
  • Algorithms Study (Coursera Stanford Algorithms): This course was mathematically intense and quite challenging. However, approaching algorithms conceptually helped me understand time complexity better and improved my problem-solving skills.
  • DDIA Study (Designing Data-Intensive Applications): Most participants were data engineers and software engineers, so I learned a lot. However, the content was too advanced for me, and I had to quit due to my graduation project workload.

Looking back, it seems like I quit all my study groups. With my graduation project nearing completion, I had to prioritize that. I think I should revisit Designing Data-Intensive Applications when I’m less busy. It’s a book that would benefit from group discussions and shared experiences.

Personal Study​

  • Causal Inference: I started strong in the first week but stopped. It’s a field I wanted to study, but I decided it’s not a priority right now. Job preparation takes precedence.
  • JavaScript: I finished Core JavaScript (코어 자바스크립트). It was concise and informative. Although I’m not pursuing frontend development, the book was easy to read.
  • School Math Lectures: I took a liberal arts course covering linear algebra, probability & statistics, and some information theory. It wasn’t too hard since I’d studied most of it before.

Graduation Project​

The project is almost done. We’ve been testing our algorithm repeatedly to ensure it works. Then, we focused on creating a poster. We had mandatory team meetings three times a week and biweekly meetings with our professor. The teaching assistant gave great feedback, helping us create a clean and visually appealing poster.

I’ll share a detailed retrospective on the graduation project later.

Job Preparation​

Resume​

I finished my English resume and applied to my top-choice company. I passed the document screening and the OA test. Now, I’m preparing for the interview. After this process, I’ll write a Korean resume.

Previous Project Code Cleanup​

I’m still organizing projects from school. Some have over 2,000 lines of code, and it’s been tough to summarize everything. I’m adding English comments and understanding the overall structure, focusing on projects mentioned in my resume.

Algorithms​

My original goal was to solve three problems daily, but I reduced it to one due to time constraints. I solve one problem each morning within a set time. Afterward, I review the solution and compare it with mine, which takes a lot of time. I’m focusing on approach strategies for easy and medium LeetCode problems.

Networking​

Gangbuk E Dosam Itto (강북에도사람있또)​

I attended a Gangbuk E Dosam Itto meetup. I expected to meet in Nowon, but it was held in Chungmuro. It was fun to go out and meet people. We discussed development, grad school, and various topics. My biggest concern was, “I don’t know which field to pursue,” and the advice to either focus on versatility or specialize deeply resonated with me.

It was half awkward, half fun, but meeting new people is always enjoyable. Sharing my concerns and hearing others’ experiences was motivating. Communities truly have a powerful impact.

Carrot Tech Meetup​

I attended the Carrot Tech Meetup by luck. I listened to Data/ML talks and networked with various Carrot teams. Networking was first-come, first-served, and I missed the chance to talk with the recruitment team, which was disappointing.

Afterward, I decided not to consider MLOps or data engineering roles. These roles are usually pursued through internal transitions, and I realized I shouldn’t hope for new grad opportunities. This conclusion also came from my data engineering study group experience.

If I want to become an MLE, I need to strengthen my ML basics and coding test skills. User service experience is a plus but not expected for new grads. Project experience, like Kaggle, was also recommended.

English Study​

I tried using ChatGPT’s Advanced Voice Mode for English conversation practice, but it was challenging. Speaking was entirely new to me, and I couldn’t make it a habit.

November Goals​

  • Reading and networking—only if they don’t interfere with job preparation
  • Solve one LeetCode problem daily
  • Interview preparation
  • Finalize graduation project exhibition
  • No study groups

My November goals are much simpler than October’s. With interviews coming up, I can’t take on too much.

I’ve written them down concretely, but I’m still afraid of breaking my own promises. But since I’ve posted this on my blog, I should at least try not to be ashamed of myself. Regardless of the outcome, I’ll give it my best shot.

item.title: 📖Open
item.description: The Key to Business Hegemony
item.content:encoded:
info

This post was written as part of the Hanbit Media I am a Reviewer activity, where I received the book for review.

Book Info​

tip

Click the book image to visit the Kyobobook store!

  • Title: Open
  • Author: Park Soo-hong
  • Publisher: Hanbit Media
  • Release Date: September 30, 2024

Intro​

When I think back to the first time I learned about open source, it was during middle school. I had just decided to become a programmer and was reading How to Be a Programmer (published by Hanbit Media). The book featured interviews with legendary programmers like Linus Torvalds and Richard Stallman, and that’s where I first encountered the term open source. (As a side note, I highly recommend reading it if you get the chance—it includes interviews with the creators of Java, C++, email, and Apple computers, among others. Though I didn’t grasp much at the time, the term became unavoidable once I entered computer science.) I even took a course where contributing to open source was a goal. Today, I still follow open-source news through various communities and social media. That’s why I was curious about this book and decided to apply as a reviewer.

Book Review​

Prologue​

The book starts with an engaging prologue:

Open has an agenda.

This line really makes you think. Over the past few years, I’ve consumed a lot of IT trend content on social media and communities, including plenty about open source. Initially, I only knew the positives—sharing knowledge, accessibility, transparency. But as I learned more, I realized there’s another side to the story. Reading this book reminded me of those nuances.

Overall Review​

The book is divided into five chapters, structured as a collection of short essays. It’s not a continuous narrative, so you can enjoy a few essays each day. Rather than deep technical explanations, it’s great for deepening your understanding of open source.

  • Chapter 1 explores the various facets of "open," starting with the reminder that while open is equal, it’s not always fair.
  • Chapter 2 dives into real-world cases and the motivations behind open source.
  • Chapter 3 discusses why open source is powerful.
  • Chapter 4 (my favorite) reveals that open source isn’t purely altruistic. It includes fascinating case studies like Microsoft vs. Linux, Samsung and Intel’s IoT open-source projects, and Google Summer of Code (GSoC)—a program I once wanted to join. Tech professionals will find this section especially engaging.
  • Chapter 5 reflects on how to navigate the open-source era. The part about hiring open-source developers was eye-opening—some companies hire talented contributors with just a few messages. I also found it amusing that some post a simple "Hiring Open Source Developers" sticky note instead of a formal job description.

Insights into the Dark Side of Open Source​

The book doesn’t shy away from the less glamorous side of open source, showing how big companies strategically use it. This helps readers move beyond romanticized notions of "sharing" and "freedom" to see how open source is a real business strategy. The shift from a technical playground to a tool for global corporate dominance is one of the book’s strongest points.

Samsung Electronics​

What surprised me most wasn’t the hidden side of open source (I’d already heard about that online), but Samsung’s role. I’d always seen Samsung as a conservative tech giant compared to others, but this book changed my view. It revealed how Samsung approaches open source in IoT and shared ongoing projects. Learning that someone like the author works there made me want to join and experience their open-source culture firsthand.

Who Should Read This Book?​

This book is for anyone curious about open source and its ecosystem. The author’s personal stories are engaging and insightful. While some prior knowledge helps, the book is accessible and will show you that open source is not just a technical tool but a powerful strategy.

item.title: 🎬First and Last Glottal Start
item.description: A truly wonderful and warm community.
item.content:encoded:
글또 10th Season​

Application​

This time, I got the chance to join the 글또 community. Every season, I wanted to participate, but sometimes I missed out because I was busy or forgot to check. Other times, reflecting on myself while writing the application felt burdensome. This time too, writing the application wasn’t easy, but it was a great experience to look back on what I’ve done and how I’ve lived. And above all, since this is the last season of 글또, I really wanted to be part of it.

Goals for 글또​

I’m busy preparing for employment, but since this is my first and last chance to join 글또, I want to participate as much as possible.

  • Join various small group channels
  • Have coffee chats, study sessions, or writing sessions with different people
  • Build healthy habits

September was an extremely tough month. Stressed from job preparation, my usual routines collapsed. I ordered delivery food three times a week and often drank alone. By chance, I got into 글또, and realizing I couldn’t go on like this, I resolved to join various small group channels in October to rebuild healthy habits.

One of my goals is to regain the pride and fulfillment I once felt by waking up at 6 AM again. It used to be so easy, but now it feels impossible. Surprisingly, the habit I thought I’d manage smoothly this week has already failed. Still, I won’t give up and will keep trying. Though I’m stressed from taking on too much too quickly, I’m grateful and happy every day.

I still feel insecure about coffee chats because I think I lack expertise. I worry if I’ll have meaningful conversations in one-on-one or group settings. Most members are professionals, and my knowledge and experience might fall short, making conversations awkward.

But I feel this worry repeats every time I meet new people. So, I’ll use 글또 to overcome it and communicate more actively. I’ll let go of the pressure to be professional and join with the mindset that it’s okay not to be perfect. After all, I’m still a student, not a professional, so there won’t be high expectations. I’ll relax and enjoy this time.

Maybe even my small knowledge or experiences could help someone. I want to listen, learn, and share my stories so we can grow together.

What I’ll Write About​

I run a separate blog and wiki. For the wiki, I wanted to document CS knowledge and insights. For the blog, I wanted to share my thoughts and experiences, not just technical posts. I also wanted to write longer, easy-to-read articles.

These are the topics I’ve thought about. I’ll probably write about these. I’d love to write something cool about ML, but I’m not sure what topic to pick yet. Maybe a good idea will come up during the activities.

October Goals​

Finally, I’ll briefly share my October goals! I always plan and set goals, but my reality never matches my expectations. Planning is tough but fun.

  • Build daily habits
    • Wake up at 6 AM
    • 30-minute fasting cardio (walking or running) in the early morning
    • 5-day weekly weight training (chest, back, shoulders, legs, arms)
    • English study with ChatGPT
    • Solve at least 3 LeetCode problems
    • Read at least 20 pages before bedtime, 1 hour before sleep
  • Join study groups
    • Algorithm study (Coursera Stanford Algorithms)
    • ETL study (Learning Spark)
    • DDIA study (Designing Data-Intensive Applications)
  • Personal study
    • Causal inference
      • Practical Causal Inference with Python
      • Causal Inference and Discovery with Python
    • JavaScript
      • Core JavaScript
    • Google Cloud AI Study Jam
  • School courses
    • Midterm report for a liberal arts class
    • Math assignments
    • Studying for a math midterm (I’m taking a math class in my final semester—what am I thinking?)
  • Graduation project
    • Collecting blood vessel data
    • Data preprocessing (CLAHE, LDC (Lightweight Dense CNN for Edge Detection))
    • Filming with a DVS (Dynamic Vision Sensor) camera
    • White blood cell counting using YOLOv8
    • Continuous experiments
  • Reading
    • Flow: The Psychology of Optimal Experience (reading it for the third time)
    • Growing Together (next book to read)
  • Job preparation
    • Resume writing
    • Reviewing past school projects and organizing them on GitHub
  • Events
    • Daangn Meetup
    • Hackathon (scheduled soon within the school)

Looking at this list, it feels overwhelming. I wrote down what I’m currently doing and what’s planned, but there might be more variables. Who knows how it’ll turn out? Personally, I wish I had more time to read books.

I’m not sure how I’m managing all this. I guess it’s just from trying to live diligently. Among the study groups, Learning Spark and Designing Data-Intensive Applications are really tough, even after reading them multiple times. I’ll need to revisit them. As for causal inference, I’m both excited and worried about how difficult it’ll be.


I visualized this using napkin.ai, recommended by 성윤님. The UI is beautiful, and I’ll use it often. Thank you for sharing the tool!

Final Words​

Writing such a long post is definitely challenging. But I hope my skills will improve with practice. How will I have changed in six months? I’m excited to see the new me through 글또. How many connections will I have made? What will I be writing? How will I be living? I’ll work harder and look forward to that time. I can do it.

Lastly, 글또, please take good care of me!

item.title: 📖AI Truths
item.description: The Age of Fear: The Clearest Truth We Must Face with Clarity
item.content:encoded:
info

This review was written as part of the Hanbit Media <I am a Reviewer> activity, where the book was provided for review.

Book Info​

tip

Click the book image to go to the Kyobobook store!

  • Title: AI Truth
  • Author: Baekjoon Lim
  • Publisher: Hanbit Media
  • Release Date: August 20, 2024

Intro​

This is my fourth technical book of 2024. With job preparation, online courses, and various projects, I’ve been struggling to finish reading technical books. Still, I applied for the "I am a Reviewer" program because I wanted to read this book. I’m a fan of the author, and my interest in AI made it an easy choice.

Book Review​

Overall Impressions​

The book starts with a fictional story imagining life with AI in ten years. Though the topic could have been dry, the novel-like opening felt like an appetizer—light yet intriguing. I found it engaging, especially since such a future seems plausible. Chapter 2 covers AI history, striking a balance between depth and accessibility. It was a great refresher on AI’s evolution.

Chapter 3 highlights AI’s surprising achievements—from deepfakes to AlphaGo and AlphaFold. Chapter 4, the book’s core, offers valuable insights for developers. By this point, it’s clear the book is up-to-date with current trends.

Chapter 5 explores real-world AI applications, while Chapter 6 discusses fears and solutions. The latter is unsettling but thought-provoking. I won’t spoil the solutions—read the book to find out.

Will Developers Be Replaced?​

Many developers or aspiring coders probably wonder if AI will replace them. I once feared this too, especially after testing Anthropic’s Claude Artifacts (in preview). It generates UI code from screenshots—React with TypeScript, just by asking. My initial thought: "Frontend developers might soon be obsolete."

But this book eased those fears. AI isn’t perfect—it hallucinates, struggles with complex abstractions, and lacks human judgment. While it produces clean code, it can’t yet handle nuanced, large-scale problems.

Moreover, if AI-generated code is misused (e.g., for unethical software), who will regulate it? Without new developers entering the field, there’s no one to enforce ethics or fix flaws. Relying solely on AI is risky.

The book argues that developers won’t be replaced—read it for more reasons.

A Healthy Fear​

Still, fear is justified. AI evolves rapidly. Early 2024 saw GPT-3.5 Turbo phased out, replaced by GPT-4, GPT-4o, and now o1-preview/o1-mini. The pace is dizzying.

The book mentions AI moving from "speaking" (statistical models) to "thinking"—a shift embodied by OpenAI’s o1. I’d lost touch with recent AI trends during job prep, but this book reminded me to stay updated.

What Should We Prepare?​

AI will keep advancing. How should we adapt?

  • Stop writing every line of code. Let AI handle repetitive tasks. Focus on complex problem-solving, communication with non-tech roles, and reviewing/testing AI-generated code.
  • Become a problem-solver. Technical skills, mathematical thinking, and deep focus remain essential—just amplified by AI.

The book quotes John Carmack, legendary game developer:

"The source of value has never been 'coding.' Don’t fixate on it. Solving problems is the core skill. Traditional programming’s discipline and precision will stay valuable, but they won’t be gatekeepers anymore. If AI becomes a better programmer than me, I’d happily manage it."

Developers are problem-solvers. Job descriptions reflect this—companies want candidates who tackle challenges creatively.

Coding is no longer exclusive. With free resources, anyone can learn. The book’s closing line resonated deeply:

"Don’t cling to coding. Don’t get attached to the tools you use. Embrace AI’s help. The real value lies in solving problems—not coding."

Who Should Read This?​

This book is for developers, especially those not in AI roles. It explains AI’s history, applications, and how to leverage it. More importantly, it challenges you to rethink your value as a developer in an AI-driven world.

If you’re curious about AI’s impact on programming, this is a must-read.

item.title: The Map of Life
item.description:
Life Map for the Glott 10th Application (Note: "글또" is transliterated as "Glott" since it appears to be a proper noun or specific program name without an official English equivalent.)
If "글또" has an official English name (e.g., "Gleat" or another term), please provide it for a more accurate translation. Otherwise, "Glott" is a phonetic rendering.
item.content:encoded:
My Life Map​

Applying to Geultto gave me a chance to reflect on the journey I’ve been through. So much has happened, and I’ve had the opportunity to look back at how I’ve changed along the way. While I’ve done short-term retrospectives before, this is one of the rare times I’ve reflected on my entire life. In this post, I’ll try to summarize my growth so far. I’m grateful to Geultto for giving me this opportunity, and to anyone reading this out of curiosity about my not-so-special life.

The Kid Who Just Loved Computers​

From a young age, I was a kid who loved computers. I signed up for after-school classes to prepare for certifications like PowerPoint, Excel, Internet, and Word Processor in the computer lab, which naturally made me close with computers. I gradually became interested in games, but since I wasn’t good at playing them, I wanted to become a programmer who creates games rather than a player. Or maybe a white-hat hacker who prevents hacking—just because it sounded fun and cool.

When I entered middle school, I started studying the basics of computers. I skimmed through books like Let’s C Programming and Cisco Networking, and solved problems on platforms like pwnable.kr or Lena's Reversing for Newbies by reading walkthroughs. I also gathered information through the Hackerschool community. I even tried applying to a digital media high school to study more professionally, but I failed. I remember my grades were good enough, but I didn’t pass the interview. Although I ended up going to a general high school, I didn’t give up on my dreams and studied programming whenever I didn’t feel like doing schoolwork. My high school physics teacher was very interested in programming (back then, "coding" wasn’t a commonly used term), so I and a friend created a club and even won an award in a school competition. Looking back, I didn’t contribute much then. I briefly studied IoT concepts and wrote a short paper, which I later read and realized was more of an informational article than a proper paper. Still, I take pride in having tried something.

Turning Point​

The most memorable moment from my high school club activities was listening to a lecture by a programmer who worked at a game company. Through him, I learned about the life of a programmer and what efforts I needed to make to get into a computer engineering department. In fact, it was he who recommended I write that paper. He helped me a lot, but I was immature at the time and had too much academic stress, so our connection naturally faded. Still, after his lecture, I became convinced that being a programmer wasn’t just a cool job—it was something I truly wanted to do. To achieve that, I needed to get into a computer engineering department, so I tried to focus more on my studies from then on.

I was also impressed by how he helped students as an educator. I remember he mentored at a specialized high school, and that image stuck with me as really cool. Back then, the Facebook page "Opentutorials (생활코딩)" was famous, and its creator "Egoing" provided web lectures that made it easy for others to learn. Seeing people like him made me realize I wanted to become someone who uses my technical knowledge to positively impact others, beyond just studying technology.

Never-Ending Effort​

After entering college, I had many moments where I wanted to give up on becoming a developer. The first was understanding double pointers and their relationship with arrays in C. I had studied it before, but it was so hard when I tried again. My peers were good at C and handled assignments well, but I struggled, making me wonder, "Is computer engineering not for me?" I was frustrated but didn’t give up. Thinking, "I’ll make it somehow," I applied for an education program run by a Microsoft MVP during summer break, as suggested by a senior. I studied C/C++, Windows API, and MFC at the Microsoft Korea building, which was my first time in an IT company—it was fascinating, and the view of Gwanghwamun was amazing.

The second challenge was in my second year, when I studied electronic circuits, Verilog, and ARM assembly. I thought college would involve practical developer skills like backend or frontend, but my department focused more on hardware as an engineering program. So, I had to study low-level concepts, which was unexpected. I was stressed and my grades weren’t good because I was forcing myself to study things I didn’t want to.

The third challenge came after my third year, when I was deciding my career path. All I had learned were CS subjects like computer architecture, operating systems, and systems programming. I barely knew frontend or backend, and wasn’t sure what to do next. My skills were limited to C, C++, Verilog, assembly, and basic web development. Then, I had to take a break for military service.

Career Crossroads​

Back home, I tried to figure out my path but couldn’t reach a clear conclusion. So, I thought, "Let’s just try everything. Experience will stack up, and a goal will emerge." I started studying random fields. Luckily, there were two libraries nearby, but they mostly had old books. Buying books was expensive for a jobless person, so I applied to be a reviewer and joined Hanbit Media’s "I Am a Reviewer" program in 2021. I’m really grateful for all the books I’ve received since then.

Around this time, I also joined the DataCamp Data Science Fellowship by "Fake Lab." It was my first time studying data engineering, and it was really tough. Besides that, I started learning Django, JavaScript, Node.js, and AI on my own, but without a plan, I burned out despite slowly accumulating knowledge.

While taking a break from development in 2023, I discovered GDG Daegu. This community reignited my motivation and taught me that communication skills are as important as technical skills for becoming an outstanding developer. It also led me to actively participate in various communities, conferences, and meetups.

There, I heard advice like, "Think about what you enjoy doing as a job." The first thing that came to mind was AI and data, which I had studied hard for. I even joined a deep learning framework implementation study at Fake Lab. However, since these fields have many career paths, I kept pondering.

In the second half of 2023, I decided to study these topics again and joined Google’s Machine Learning Bootcamp. It was a fun experience to review ML basics and meet great people. After returning to school, I joined my university’s GDSC as an ML Member and am now almost certain about becoming an ML engineer, though I still keep questioning my path.

The Me Today​

Now, I’m preparing for graduation and job hunting. Looking back, the field I’ve studied most seriously is AI. However, reading job postings makes me constantly think about giving up and switching paths. Most companies require a master’s degree or equivalent skills, and I don’t fit either category.

Still, I believe I can overcome this. I’ve done it before, and I’ll keep going. Just as I never gave up in tough moments, I’m sure I’ll prevail this time too.

item.title: 📖Developing LLM-based AI Services with LangChain
item.description: Learn RAG from a Current AI Specialist! | Implement 8 Services with LangChain, OpenAI API, and Streamlit!
item.content:encoded:
Book Info​

tip

Click the book image to go to the Kyobobook site!

  • Title: Developing AI Services with LangChain: Building LLM-Based Applications
  • Author: Ji-Young Seo
  • Publisher: Gilbut
  • Published: 2024-02-27

Intro​

LLMs (Large Language Models) are so trendy these days that even during exam season, I carved out some time to study them. As someone studying AI, I already knew the basics of what LLMs are and how to use them. But I picked up this book for a refresher—and honestly, because it was super thin. Plus, the author works at Microsoft, so I figured there might be some exclusive tips!

Book Review​

Great for Developers Not in ML​

I’d recommend this book to developers without a machine learning background. It covers general AI concepts and isn’t too code-heavy, making it a light read. It even walks you through setting up Conda, getting an OpenAI API key, and obtaining a Hugging Face token—so it’s a solid introductory guide.

For me, the RAG section was a helpful refresher, and I got to try LangChain for the first time (it’s not bad!). The book also lists LangChain projects you can explore later—definitely worth checking out. This read inspired me to brainstorm how to integrate LangChain and LLMs into my own projects. Time to start a LangChain project soon!

Recommended For​

If you’re curious about LLMs and want a quick yet practical intro, this book is for you. 🚀

item.title: 📖How to Become a Better Programmer
item.description: 39 Practical Tips from Senior Developers You Can Implement Right Away
item.content:encoded:
info

This post is part of the Hanbit Media I am a Reviewer activity, written after receiving the book for review.

Book Info​

tip

Click the book cover to visit the Kyobobook page!

  • Title: Becoming a Better Programmer
  • Author: Pete Goodliffe
  • Translators: Wonjae Choi, Jeonhee Kang, Jaedeok Ahn, Yoonhwa Nam
  • Publisher: Hanbit Media
  • Release Date: April 30, 2024

Intro​

This is my second technical book of 2024. Lately, I’ve been juggling multiple projects and reading various books, which has made it hard to finish them all. Still, I picked this one up because it seemed approachable, and I was curious: What more should I do to become a better programmer?

Book Review​

A Book That Makes You Reflect​

This book explores how programmers can grow in their careers. As I read, I realized how much I’ve overlooked certain aspects and what I should prioritize. It made me reflect a lot: Do I care enough about my code? Do I revisit my code? Is writing test code really that important? These questions stuck with me.

A Senior Developer’s Mentorship​

Reading this felt like having a senior programmer guide me step by step—sharing insights on how to think and act as a developer. Even though I’m not working at a company and don’t have mentors, this book gave me that experience. The "Final Thoughts" section includes reflection prompts, and I found myself brainstorming even beyond those questions. If I get the chance, I’d love to do a study group with others using this book.

Recommended Readers​

If you’re a programmer looking to grow—especially if you’re a newcomer, junior developer, or even a student—this book is for you. It’s a great read for anyone who wants to reflect, improve, and become a better programmer.

item.title: 📖The Essential Guide to Deep Learning
item.description: From Linear Algebra and Probability to Deep Learning with PyTorch: Theory and Practice
item.content:encoded:
info

This review was written as part of the Hanbit Media I am a Reviewer activity, where I received the book for review purposes.

Book Info​

tip

Click the book cover to visit the Kyobobook store!

  • Title: Fundamentals of Deep Learning
  • Authors: Nitish Srivastava, Nikhil Buduma, Joe Papa
  • Translators: Jaehoon Choi, Seongjae Cha
  • Editors: Taeung Sung, Yunho Maeng
  • Publisher: Hanbit Media
  • Publication Date: February 2, 2024

Intro​

It’s already 2024. Studying deep learning has been challenging so far—and it’s still tough. This year, I’ll keep pushing to learn more about machine learning. There are so many books I want to read. Thanks to Hanbit Media’s I am a Reviewer program, my first IT book of 2024 is Fundamentals of Deep Learning.

Book Review​

Foundational Math​

The book starts with concise yet essential explanations of linear algebra and probability. However, if you’ve never studied these topics before, you might find them difficult. The explanations are clear, but even I struggled a bit when revisiting them. That’s expected—Chapters 1 and 2 alone could fill a university course. Studying linear algebra and probability beforehand would make this book more rewarding. Still, it was refreshing to revisit these concepts, especially since the authors explain why they matter, which motivates readers.

Effort from Authors & Translators​

If I were a translator, I’d probably hate translating this book. The sentences are dense and technically challenging. The authors clearly tried to simplify complex math concepts, and the translators must have worked hard to preserve that clarity in Korean. The presence of two editors likely helped polish the text.

Korean Terminology​

Since I studied machine learning in English, the heavy use of Korean terms felt awkward at times. However, English equivalents were always provided (e.g., 고유벡터eigenvectors^{eigenvectors}eigenvectors, 사후확률posterior probability^{posterior \ probability}posterior probability, L2 규제화regularization^{regularization}regularization). Most terms were translated, while untranslatable ones like dropout remained in English. This is unavoidable in translations, but it was a bit disappointing.

What Sets This Book Apart​

You’ll notice many footnotes throughout the book—this is a key difference from other deep learning texts. Whenever a key concept appears, the footnotes cite the original research papers. The book feels like a curated summary of foundational papers, explained by the authors. While some details felt like TMI (Too Much Information), the academic tone was engaging. It made sense why the title is Fundamentals of Deep Learning.

PyTorch​

PyTorch is introduced in Chapter 5. Before that, the book focuses on core deep learning concepts. It doesn’t deeply explain PyTorch—you’ll need to look up specifics elsewhere. That’s fair, since this isn’t a PyTorch tutorial. Familiarity with PyTorch basics (e.g., via Opentutorials (생활코딩) PyTorch Tutorial) would make reading smoother.

Broad Coverage​

The book touches on CNNs, RNNs, reinforcement learning, generative models, XAI, and even Neural Turing Machines (NTM). While CNNs and RNNs are well-explained, topics like XAI and NTM felt too brief and challenging. Still, it was interesting to see these fields introduced.

Recommended Audience​

This isn’t a beginner-friendly book. If you’re new to deep learning, you might get overwhelmed. However, if you already understand the basics, this book is a great resource for deepening your knowledge. It’s especially useful if you want to revisit concepts with clear, detailed explanations.
